questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with a history of recurrent urinary tract infections. His blood pressure is normal, and physical examination is unremarkable. His mother reports that he had a febrile urinary tract infection six months ago. Renal ultrasonography showed no hydronephrosis or stones, but the pediatrician is concerned about renal cortical damage. Which of the following imaging studies is most appropriate for evaluating the child for renal cortical scarring?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. DMSA

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Renal cortical scarring is commonly caused by vesicoureteric reflux (VUR) , which is a major risk factor for recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs) in children. The most appropriate investigation to detect renal cortical scarring is a DMSA (Dimercaptosuccinic Acid) scan , which is a static nuclear medicine scan used to assess the morphology of the kidneys.

  • • DMSA (Dimercaptosuccinic Acid) scan
  • • static nuclear medicine scan
  • • morphology

  • • DMSA scan:
  • • Detects cortical defects and scarring due to recurrent infections. Provides a static image of the kidney to identify areas of reduced uptake, indicating scarred or non-functioning renal tissue. Technetium-99m is used as the tracer in the scan.
  • • Detects cortical defects and scarring due to recurrent infections.
  • • cortical defects and scarring
  • • Provides a static image of the kidney to identify areas of reduced uptake, indicating scarred or non-functioning renal tissue.
  • • static image
  • • Technetium-99m is used as the tracer in the scan.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. USG (Ultrasonography): Ultrasonography is the first-line investigation to assess structural abnormalities and hydronephrosis but is not sensitive for detecting renal scarring.

  • • first-line investigation

  • • Option C. MCU (Micturating Cystourethrography): MCU is the investigation of choice for detecting vesicoureteric reflux (VUR) but does not provide information about cortical scarring. It is used to visualize reflux of urine from the bladder into the ureters during micturition.

  • • vesicoureteric reflux (VUR)
  • • Option D. DTPA (Diethylenetriamine Pentaacetic Acid) scan: DTPA is a functional nuclear scan used to assess glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and renal function and detect obstruction . It is not used for detecting cortical scars, as it shows overall function rather than morphology.
  • • Option D. DTPA (Diethylenetriamine Pentaacetic Acid) scan:

questions.explanation:

MRI findings often include cystic lesions with or without a scolex (the head of the larva), and ring-enhancing lesions when the cyst is dying. MR spectroscopy may show elevated choline and reduced N-acetyl aspartate (NAA), but a prominent lipid-lactate peak is not typical.

MR spectroscopy in PML typically shows a reduction in NAA, reflecting neuronal loss or damage, without a prominent lipid-lactate peak.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presents to the clinic with localized pain in her left knee that worsens at night. She has no significant past medical history and reports no recent trauma. Physical examination reveals mild swelling and tenderness over the proximal tibia. Laboratory studies show normal white blood cell count and inflammatory markers. An X-ray of the knee is performed, revealing a well-defined lytic lesion with sclerotic margins in the proximal tibial metaphysis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Brodie’s abscess

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Brodie’s abscess is a form of subacute osteomyelitis that typically presents as a well-defined lytic lesion with sclerotic margins, usually in the metaphyseal region of long bones. The classic presentation includes localized pain that worsens at night, mild swelling, and tenderness. The sclerotic rim seen on the X-ray is pathognomonic for subacute osteomyelitis. Unlike acute osteomyelitis, Brodie’s abscess is less aggressive and shows a defined, contained appearance on imaging.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Osteoid osteoma: Osteoid osteoma typically presents as a cortical-based lesion in the diaphysis of long bones. It causes pain that worsens at night and is often relieved by NSAIDs. However, the X-ray shows a metaphyseal lesion rather than a cortical diaphyseal lesion, ruling out osteoid osteoma.
  • • Option B. Osteoid osteoma:
  • • Option C. Ewing sarcoma: Ewing sarcoma is a highly aggressive bone tumor that commonly presents in the diaphysis with periosteal reaction (often an "onion-skin" appearance) rather than a well-defined lesion with sclerotic margins. Additionally, systemic symptoms like fever and elevated inflammatory markers may be present, which are absent here.
  • • Option C. Ewing sarcoma:
  • • Option D. Adamantinoma: Adamantinoma is a rare, slow-growing tumor most commonly found in the diaphysis of the tibia. It typically appears as a more destructive lesion without the characteristic sclerotic margins seen in Brodie’s abscess. This lesion’s metaphyseal location also argues against adamantinoma.
  • • Option D. Adamantinoma:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Brodie’s abscess is a subacute form of osteomyelitis that presents as a well-defined lytic lesion with a sclerotic rim, typically in the metaphysis of long bones, and causes localized pain that worsens at night.
  • ➤ Brodie’s abscess

questions.text: 28-year women with history of an ectopic pregnancy presents with subfertility of 3 years. She complains of recurrent vaginal discharge. A transvaginal ultrasound reveals the following. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Hydrosalpinx

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The ultrasound shows a tubular, anechoic (black) structure, which is indicative of a fluid-filled cavity. Hydrosalpinx refers to fluid accumulation in the fallopian tube due to chronic inflammation or infection. The retort-shaped appearance with incomplete septations on ultrasound is classic for hydrosalpinx. The fluid content results in an anechoic (black) image due to the absence of internal echoes.
  • • The patient's history of ectopic pregnancy and infertility supports the diagnosis, as hydrosalpinx is often associated with fallopian tube damage secondary to infections or previous tubal surgeries.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Ovarian malignancy: Ovarian malignancies generally present as complex cystic or solid masses with irregular walls and internal vascularity on Doppler imaging. They do not typically appear as simple, fluid-filled anechoic structures.
  • • Option A. Ovarian malignancy:
  • • Option B. Chocolate cyst (Endometrioma): A chocolate cyst (endometrioma) appears as a well-rounded, homogenous lesion with internal low-level echoes due to old, clotted blood. Unlike hydrosalpinx, it is not completely anechoic and has a "ground glass" appearance.
